title: Do autistic people like cats? - Quora

response.answer_text: I like cats a LOT. Of course, I’m one autistic among perhaps a hundred or so million people in the world with autistic traits. It’s hard to generalize about 100,000,000 people. However, taking the question in the spirit intended - more or less, “Do cats have traits that autistics might favor in pets,” I think the answer is clearly yes. One theme of mine is that autistics take in and give off social cues worse, slower, or differently from neuronormal people. Part of that seems to be because we don’t multi-task well - and taking in social cues is the consummate exercise in multi-tasking - and part of it seems to be the converse, to wit, that we end to carry many things out - including social interactions - in linear fashion. Socially adept people don’t put off their social cues in linear fashion, however. Given this, though we can somewhat fall flat socially, I think it’s fair to say that we are resistant to charm, manipulation, and social engineering. Dogs are the ultimate charmers - and the ultimate manipulators. I’ve read that dogs are the only non-primate animal that can read human body language fluently. Apparently not even wolves can do that. Modern Dog Magazine online has a sadly undated article on the ability of dogs to read human body language titled How Dogs Read Human Body Language. It’s here: How Dogs Read Human Body Language One highlight of the article is that “…Daniel J. Povinelli, a psychologist at the University of Southwestern Louisiana, found that our closest animal relatives, chimpanzees, were initially quite poor at [the task given in the experiment]. (Actually, so were three-year-old human children, though they were better than the apes.) However … The dogs could immediately interpret the signals indicating the location of the food four times better than the apes, and more than twice as well as the young children, even if the experimenter was a stranger.” Anyone with a dog knows this. I can’t “read dog” well, but I know that dogs can read me, and I resent their frequent attempts at manipulation, which I read as intrusive begging. Of course, simply not liking dogs does not mean that one favors cats [though I’ve set that up as sort of a dichotomy in this answer], but there ARE reasons to think cats are a good match with autistics. An opinion piece on the website Medical Daily dated July 19th, 2015 is a good read for anyone interested in pets as friends or service animals for people with autism. Here's the article: How Cats Can Help Children With Autism Become More Social The article discusses research and the personal observations of the author - Ed Cara - and goes into some detail on the benefits of dogs, cats and even hamsters for people with ASD. It takes a special look at cats, highlighting how cats seem to be a good match with autistics - perhaps because they seem to have a similar mind-frame - and how cats increase pro-social behaviors and reduce anxiety in people with autism. I have an autistic services cat and an autistic services dog. The cat is a “barn cat” given to us from a friend in the Indiana countryside. I love her sociability - unlike most cats, she will actually run towards someone if she thinks they are running away from her - but I also love how she keeps her distance. She perseverates like most cats - especially on the fish - and I find that an amusing echo of my own perseveration and “trances.” I’m not the only one so amused: here’s a link to a humorous book on the matter: All Cats Have Asperger Syndrome: Kathy Hoopmann: 0884667904259: Amazon.com: Books For the curious, here is a picture of my cat’s ESA, or emotional service animal, ID. Emotional services cats for autistics are a real thing:

Autistic people don't, as a class, dislike cats. That's the most information I can offer. I know some autistic people who are afraid of animals, some who like dogs and are indifferent to cats, some who like cats very much, and don't like dogs, some who love all animals, and the variations go on. If the asker has a practical reason for asking, such as "My girlfriend's son is autistic, and I have two cats; will this be a problem if we decide to move in together," you need to ask her son, if he is high functioning enough how he feels about cats. If he doesn't have much language, then ask her. Aside from some reason like that, it's kind of a silly question. The only other reason I can imagine is that someone has told the asker that some person can't be autistic because he likes cats, due to this other person being misinformed about the frequency of fear of animals among autistic people. Back when most autistic people spent most of their lives in institutions they rarely were exposed to animals, and so if they did happen to see a pet, they often became frightened because it was unfamiliar. This led to the conclusion that it was common for autistics to be afraid of animals; however, a lot of behaviors that are attributed to "autism" are really institutional behaviors, and in fact, there is no “rule of thumb,” or whatever, that autistic people are likely to be afraid of animals. Some autistic people have a heightened startle reflex, so animals that appear with no warning, or bark, or make other sudden noises may bother these particular people, but that just means that perhaps a slightly larger percentage of autistic people prefer not to be around animals— the percentage is still pretty close to what it is for neurotypicals, in my experience. The best that can be said as an answer to this question is that autistic people tend to vary in their like or dislike of pets about the same as other people. Allergies happen pretty much with equal incidence and severity among autistic people too. This is another example of “If you’ve met one autistic person, you’ve met one autistic person.”

Really depends on the person, you can’t have mass-agreement in people just because they all have the same condition. Back to the question anyway! Me and my best friend both really like cats, I’m really an animal person in general, they’re one of my main interests but Abigail doesn’t like dogs that much since they’re a lot bigger and louder and boisterous, they easily overload her senses where as cats are more docile and quiet, they’re less full on. I think that’s why a lot of autistic people like us like cats a lot, can’t speak for everyone but I know a lot of other ASD people who own or would like to own a cat because of their softness, calmness and just being there for you and often up for a play and cuddle but not as excitable or demanding. That being said I’ll always love dogs (and most other animals) but not everyone can cope with the same things. Hope that helps/was interesting/wasn’t too waffly, I waffle a lot.

I always considered myself to be a dog person. In fact, I had an obsession with wolves growing up. I also had pet rats as a kid. The last thing I wanted was a cat. All that changed about 2 years ago when the neighbors cat decided to adopt my fiance and me. She literally moved in and decided we were going to be her People from now on. Luckily her other Mommy decided to work out a shared custody arrangement (as if you can tell a cat where she can and can't go...) or things could have gotten awkward pretty fast. Since being adopted though, I've noticed that she and I share a lot of similar traits...neither of us like having things moved around, or schedules changed. I'm working my way to having a hospital wing named after me (it feels like) and she completely tweaks out when I'm gone...same as when my fiance has to be away for any length of time over a few hours' time.  I can't think of life without our adopted Owner now (cats aren't owned, they own people) and I wouldn't have it any other way.

Why not? I adore cats. They’re actually a lot easier for me to understand, love and relate to than humans. Unlike humans: They’re motivated by few, simple, well-known principles and don’t have hidden agendas that I cannot fathom. Their subterfuges are innocent and straightforward enough for me to decipher.They don’t have a pecking order, a complex hierarchy of power and influence (politics) that take someone autistic a lifetime to decode and in the meantime make us fail miserably professionally and socially.They don’t reject us for being too nice, too brainy, too different, too weird, too quiet, too talkative, too underdeveloped socio-economically, etc.They always act by logic rather than self-delusion. They don’t remain loyal to an abuser - they soon leave.They’re kindred souls; as many say, all cats are autistic.

Original Question: Do autistic people like cats? When taking a question like this, it’s tough to break it down. It relies on generalizing an entire mass of people, and referring to that mass as a singular. So, the answer to the question has to be a resounding yes, and then no. Because it’s also a ridiculous generalization. I like cats, I’m autistic, but not all autistic people are simply going to love cats. I feel as though you may have been wondering, for autistic people, if it’s even possible to like cats? Do autistic people have the ability to like cats, however? Yes. Yes we do.

One autistic may like one thing, another autistic may like another. When you’ve met one autistic, you’ve met one autistic. Your milage may vary. Personally, I love cats! I grew up with three cats, then we got another (plus a dog and a bird), although not all at the same time. Currently, we only have one.  Meet The Tasmanian Devil (AKA Taz), my six year old cat. Believe me, he has that name for a very good reason. He’s not the nicest of cats in most cases and he’s a huge trouble maker, but I love him.  If I see a cat, I always make sure to give them space, but I absolutely adore them. My friends can tell you, since I have a tendency to ignore them whenever there’s an animal around… oops.

I have autism but I don’t like cats, Its not because I’m a cat hater its just I was overly exposed to cats as a kid and have had five in my lifetime.I had a mean ass cat when I was a kid, and knew a lady who had a mean cat so I guess thats why I'm more of a dog person I mean I volunteer at an animal shelter and hang out with cats and kittens all day,I also play with dogs and puppies I currently have 3 cats at my house, One is a stray feral kitten named Sparky the other is an elderly cat my aunt gave to me because she moved to a no pet condo. I have a 15 year old cat Kit who was born to my very first cat (she is the mean cat btw) Anyways n0t all autistic people like cats, I prefer a great dane, an irish settler, a Labrador, a cavalier king Charles spaniel, a st bernard, a great Pyrenees, and 2 coonhounds

It's difficult to answer that question as the underlying assumption is that people with autism can be generalized on things that they like. Imagine asking "Do girls like cats?" Answer is: maybe? Probably? I don't know. Cats are cute. Depends on who you're asking. Don't forget that people with autism are people too. They have varying likes and dislikes, just like you do. :)

It all really depends on the person. One autistic person could find everything about them to be sensory heaven, and it might be sensory hell for others. The majority of autistic children I’ve worked with have LOVED cats, and we’ve brought in therapy cats which they’ve had a great time with. Cats are amazing stims auditory and sensory wise, and larger cats can be good pressure stims (just put them on yourself and if they’re lazy, they’ll just lay there).

Yes, autistic people like cats. Autistic people generally love all animals and cats are definitely right on top of the list of many Autistic beings . Cats and Dogs have a calming influence on them and they thus play a therapeutic role in the  person's life . Not only that, cats are generally easier to take care of and that makes them a good choice for the autistic person.

I like cats. I'm autistic. There is nothing intrinsic connecting those two statements. I have no idea if I would like cats if I wasn't autistic, because it is impossible for me to not be autistic. I have never not been autistic. So the first statement can feasibly be replaced with any other statement. (Scientific studies need to be performed. Lock someone in a room and introduce cats into that room until they start screaming.)

Well, my husband is on the spectrum and he likes cats ok, though he doesn't seek them out as pets. My friend Jo is probably on the spectrum ( no formal “ diagnosis” but many of the traits) and she loves all animals except dogs. My brother is on the spectrum and he likes all animals. And my friend Caleb was on the spectrum and hated all animals, especially cats. So I'd say that it's a good mix.

Before I answer this question, let me ask you a question. Do nuerotypical people like cats? If you were asked that question you would probably be confused because it varies from person to person. That being said a lot of autistic people I know like cats, so they can, but it's not necessarily a given.

Now, I am going off of limited experience, but I will do my best to answer your question fully. My brother was diagnosed with autism almost two years ago, and lives in a house with two cats. He feeds them and loves cuddling with them all the time. He has never been violent towards our pets and he has told me he is glad we got them, because they make him feel more responsible.
Many autistics like cats and find them good company, but as Tiffany pointed out, autistics are individuals and have varying opinions just like everyone else.

I love cats & I always have. They love me on their own terms. I like that. One of mine when I adopted her acted shy and depressed. Gave her time to reach out and now she is as sweetly affectionate as anyone could wish for. They are uncomplicated and accepting when people aren't.

It’s tricky but I can answer as a mild autistic person and I love cats. Im not saying all autistic people love cats, I’m just saying I do. I have 4 cats so that might be an excuse but one of my cats has attached to me. That might be my autism, that might not.

My wife points out cats to me by saying “No, no! No, you did not see that! That does not exist!” Cue loud squeeing from yours truly. If I know a cat is going to show up on TV, I can suppress the squealing. If I unexpectedly see a cat, then I squee loudly and happily. I do the same for dogs. My wife points out other animals to me because she wants me to appreciate other animals as well as cats.

It varies. I like cats. They kind of remind me of me. I have seven of them, though it'll be six soon as one is going to live with the mother in law. They're all jumpy little assholes that like to sleep. I can empathise with them on that front. One of my acquaintances that is also on the spectrum refuses to visit the house as he hates cats with a passion (nothing personal, they just scare him.) Many others will range from obsession to terror and everything in between, regardless of their status on the spectrum.
Some of us do.  My father and I are both on the spectrum.  I like cats.  He finds them obnoxious.
My 9 year old has PDDNOS Autism and prefers his cat to all else, even me sometimes. The other children in his group, some do some do not, depends on the person.

Edited: original question: Can autistic people like cats? Well, whose permission are you asking for? It is like asking, “Can superman wear his pants over his underwear?” The answer to that would be - he could. But the choice would be his/hers to make, ain't it?

Much like any neurotypical, it varies from person to person. I personally prefer cats over any other animal, including other people. Another person on the spectrum could just as easily not be able to tolerate cats at all. Others can fall anywhere on between the two extremes.
love them  that’s me
Yes. I have autism and I like my cat. I don’t have a picture, but I’ll update with one later, maybe. Edit 4/16/18: My cat:
I. LOVE. CATS.
yes yes and yes this is tinsel
I do!
